org.strongback

Class Strongback

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.strongback.Strongback

  • @ThreadSafe
public final class Strongback
extends Object
    Access point for a number of the higher-level Strongback functions. This class can be used within robot code or within unit tests.

    Configuration

    Strongback will by default use the system logger, FPGA time (if available), and an executor that operates on a 5 millisecond execution period. If these defaults are not acceptable, then the Strongback library needs to be configured programmatically before you use it.

    To configure Strongback, do the following once in the initialization of your robot (perhaps very early in the IterativeRobot.robotInit() method):

    1. call the configure() method to obtain the Strongback.Configurator instance,
    2. call any combination of the "use" or "set" methods on the Strongback.Configurator instance,
    3. call the initialize() method on the Strongback.Configurator instance.
    After that, the configuration should not be adjusted again, and any of the other Strongback methods can be used.

    For example, the following code configures Strongback to use what happen to be the default logger, time system, 5ms executor (that uses busy-wait loops rather than Thread.sleep(long)), and automatically recording data and events to files on the RoboRIO: 

     Strongback.configure()
           .useSystemLogger(Logger.Level.INFO)
           .useFpgaTime()
           .useExecutionPeriod(5, TimeUnit.MILLISECONDS)
           .useExecutionWaitMode(WaitMode.BUSY)
           .initialize();
 // Strongback is ready to use ...

    • Method Detail

      • configure

        public static Strongback.Configurator configure()
        Get the Strongback library configurator. Any configuration changes will take effect only after the Strongback.Configurator.initialize() method is called.
        Returns:
        the configuration; never null

      • start

        public static void start()
        Start the Strongback functions, including the Executor, command scheduler, and the data recorder. This does nothing if Strongback is already started.

        This is often useful to call in IterativeRobot.autonomousInit() to start Strongback and prepare for any autonomous based commands and start recording data and events.

        See Also:
        restart()

      • restart

        public static void restart()
        Ensure that Strongback is started and, if it was already running, kill all currently-running commands. It is equivalent to calling both #start() and #killAllCommands(), although it is a bit more efficient.

        This is often useful to use in IterativeRobot.teleopInit() to ensure Strongback is running and to cancel any commands that might still be running from autonomous mode.

        See Also:
        start(), killAllCommands()

      • disable

        public static void disable()
        Stop all currently-scheduled activity and flush all recorders. This is typically called by robot code when when the robot becomes disabled. Should the robot re-enable, all aspects of Strongback will continue to work as before it was disabled.

      • shutdown

        public static void shutdown()

      • executor

        public static Executor executor()
        Get Strongback's automatically-configured Executor that repeatedly and efficiently performs asynchronous work on a precise interval using a single separate thread. Multiple Executables can be registered with this executor, and doing so ensures that all of those Executables are run on the same thread. This is more efficient than using multiple Executor instances, which each require their own thread.

        Strongback's data recorder, switch reactor, and internal scheduler are already registered with this internal Executor, and therefore all use this single thread efficiently for all asynchronous processing.

        However, care must be taken to prevent overloading the executor. Specifically, the executor must be able to perform all work for all registered Executables during the configured execution interval. If too much work is added, the executor may fall behind.

        Returns:
        Strongback's executor; never null
        See Also:
        Strongback.Configurator.useExecutionPeriod(long, TimeUnit), Strongback.Configurator.useExecutionTimerMode(org.strongback.Strongback.Configurator.TimerMode)

      • logger

        public static Logger logger()
        Get Strongback's global Logger implementation.
        Returns:
        Strongback's logger instance; never null
        See Also:
        Strongback.Configurator.useSystemLogger(org.strongback.Logger.Level), Strongback.Configurator.useCustomLogger(Function)

        Parameters:

      • submit

        public static void submit(Runnable executeFunction)
        Submit to Strongback's internal scheduler a Command that runs the supplied function one time and completes immediately.
        Parameters:
        executeFunction - the function to be called during execution; may not be null

      • submit

        public static void submit(Runnable first,
                          double delayInSeconds,
                          Runnable second)
        Submit to Strongback's internal scheduler a Command that runs the supplied function one time, waits the prescribed amount of time, and then calls the second function.
        Parameters:
        first - the first function to be called; may not be null
        delayInSeconds - the delay in seconds after the first function completes; must be positive
        second - the second function to be called after the delay; may be null if not needed

      • submit

        public static void submit(BooleanSupplier function,
                          double maxDurationInSeconds)
        Submit to Strongback's internal scheduler a Command that runs the supplied function one or more times until it returns false or until the prescribed maximum time has passed, whichever comes first.
        Parameters:
        function - the function to be called at least one time and that should return true if it is to be called again; may not be null
        maxDurationInSeconds - the maximum amount of time that the first function should be repeatedly called; must be positive

      • submit

        public static void submit(BooleanSupplier first,
                          double maxDurationInSeconds,
                          Runnable second)
        Submit to Strongback's internal scheduler a Command that runs the supplied function one or more times until it returns false or until the prescribed maximum time has passed, and then calls the second function.
        Parameters:
        first - the first function to be called at least one time and that should return true if it is to be called again; may not be null
        maxDurationInSeconds - the maximum amount of time that the first function should be repeatedly called; must be positive
        second - the second function to be called after the delay; may be null if not needed

      • killAllCommands

        public static void killAllCommands()
        Kill all currently-running commands.

      • flushRecorders

        public static void flushRecorders()
        Flush all data that has been recorded but not written to disk.

      • switchReactor

        public static SwitchReactor switchReactor()
        Get Strongback's SwitchReactor that can be used to call functions when switches change state or while they remain in a specific state. The switch reactor is registered with the executor, so it periodically polls the registered switches and, based upon the current and previous states invokes the appropriate registered functions.

        This is a great way to perform some custom logic based upon Switch states. For example, you could submit a specific command every time a button is pressed, or submit a command when a button is released, or run a command while a button is pressed. See SwitchReactor for details.

        Returns:
        the switch reactor; never null
        See Also:
        SwitchReactor, Strongback.Configurator.useExecutionPeriod(long, TimeUnit)

      • dataRecorder

        public static DataRecorder dataRecorder()
        Get Strongback's DataRecorder that can be used to register switches, motors, and other functions that provide recordable data. Once data providers have been registered, Strongback will only begin recording data after Strongback is started, at which time the data recorder will automatically and repeatedly poll the data providers and write out the information to its log. Strongback should be disabled when the robot is disabled to flush any unwritten data and prevent recording data while in disabled mode. When the robot is enabled, it should again be started.
        Returns:
        the data recorder; never null
        See Also:
        DataRecorder, Strongback.Configurator.recordDataTo(Function), Strongback.Configurator.recordDataToFile(String), Strongback.Configurator.recordDataToNetworkTables(), Strongback.Configurator.recordDuration(int), Strongback.Configurator.recordNoData()

      • eventRecorder

        public static EventRecorder eventRecorder()
        Get Strongback's EventRecorder used to record non-regular events and activities. If Strongback is configured to automatically record commands, then all changes to command states are recorded in this event log. However, custom code can also explicitly record events to the same log.
        Returns:
        the event recorder
        See Also:
        EventRecorder, Strongback.Configurator.recordCommands(), Strongback.Configurator.recordNoCommands(), Strongback.Configurator.recordEventsToFile(String, long), Strongback.Configurator.recordNoEvents()

      • excessiveExecutionTimeCounts

        public static long excessiveExecutionTimeCounts()
        Get the number of times the executor has been unable to execute all work within the time period specified in the configuration.
        Returns:
        the number of excessive delays
